Survey 1 was conducted from 21 to 29 February (weighted mean 26 February) and survey 2 was conducted on 7 March. Symptoms were re-assessed on 21 - 23 March 2020 (follow up) for all subjects showing no symptoms at the time of testing. We did not reassess symptoms at survey 2, only at follow up.   2.	The followed up time was hence 2 weeks for those identified at round 2 and 3 to 4 weeks for those identified at round 1.  3.	The definition of symptomatic used is: a subject who required hospitalization and/or reported fever (yes/no or a temperature above 37 degrees Celsius) and/or cough and/or at least two of the following symptoms: sore throat, headache, diarrhoea, vomit, asthenia, muscle pain, joint pain, loss of taste or smell, shortness of breath. An asymptomatic infection is a PCR positive infection who does not show symptoms (as in the definition) at the time of testing nor at any time up to follow up (end of March). A pre-symptomatic infection is a PCR positive infection who does not show symptoms (as in the definition) at the time of testing but develops them afterwards, as assessed at follow up. It is possible in theory that someone classified as asymptomatic develops symptoms after follow up - in this case the infection would be pre-symptomatic but we would have misclassified it as asymptomatic. The minimum follow up time was 2 weeks, and given the current estimates on the incubation period this should have captured most pre-symptomatic infections.     I would be very interested in the systematic review that you are conducting, could you please share the results with me when they become available?     I hope this helps, please let me know if anything is unclear.     Best wishes,   Ilaria
